PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE:     An unfortunately common syndrome that affects many individuals following stroke is an impairment in speech and language. A number of treatments are available for these impairments but their effectiveness varies among different individuals. The current study is focused on identifying the brain factors that explain why some individuals respond better to speech treatment than others. We will do this by using state-of-the-art MRI brain imaging techniques. These imaging methods will also allow us to measure changes in the brains of individuals that occur in response to the treatment. Findings from this study will provide clinicians with critical information that they can use to tailor their treatment plans to those patients who can best benefit from a particular speech intervention. PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE:      Parkinson's disease (PD) is a devastating progressive neurological condition. The cost of management of VA population suffering from PD is phenomenal. Neuroinflammation is central in PD pathology. GPR109A is an anti-inflammatory receptor which is present everywhere in the body especially in the immune cells. We have observed up-regulation of this receptor in the substantia nigra and white blood cells (WBCs) of the PD patients. Niacin (Vitamin B3) acts as an agonist to this receptor and our preliminary findings in PD patients demonstrates its regulatory effects on GPR109A levels in WBCs. We propose to use niacin to facilitate rehabilitation of VA PD patients. Also we will study the mechanisms involved in the anti-inflammatory role of niacin via GPR109A in in-vitro models. Our goal is to ameliorate motor, coordination and cognitive symptoms of PD patients and find new avenues in treating our Veteran suffering from PD.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Cerebellar hypoplasia and medulloblastoma are severe childhood neurological disorders that both result from failed regulation of cerebellar development. PHR: Each year, roughly one million patient falls occur in United States (US) hospitals resulting in over 250,000 injuries and 11,000 deaths. Although it is well understood that the physical hospital environment contributes to nearly 40% of severe or fatal hospital falls, there are significant gaps in our knowledge about the relationship between inpatient unit design and fall rates. The few studies that have examined unit design have been conducted in a single hospital or a small number of inpatient units, limiting generalizability. Thus, the goal of this study is to identify unit design factors contributing to inpatient falls within the VHA. We are proposing a study to explore the relationship between unit design and patient falls in VA medical/surgical units. We will utilize a qualitative approach to investigate staff and management perceptions with environmental factors that contribute to patient falls (Aim 1) and will use quantitative approaches in Aim 2 to identify med/surg units with higher- or lower-than expected fall rates and identify spatial and environmental factors that distinguish them.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT  Although mental health interventions, particularly psychological well-being (PWB) interventions such as contemplative practices, are recognized as effective means for improving public health for both current and future generations, little is known about the efficacy of PWB interventions in real-life settings, and how intervention success varies on an individual basis. The proposed study will harness the ecological momentary assessment (EMA) design to create an integrated tool for (1) multifaceted assessment of PWB and (2) delivering PWB interventions in real life settings, with person-centered statistical inference tailored for developing and evaluating EMA-based approaches to increase PWB. This rigorous assessment approach will have broad implications for reducing national health disparities. ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Joint replacement surgery is the most common inpatient surgery in the Veterans Health Administration (VHA). 14,349 primary joint replacement cases were performed in the VHA system in 2015. Early failure of joint replacement is very costly to the patient and to the health care system. It is imperative that we improve our ability to monitor the performance of implants in the VA and identify poorly performing implants as early as possible. We propose a pilot project to extract and evaluate joint replacement prosthesis implantation and explantation information from the VA Corporate Data Warehouse (CDW). If we are able to achieve this goal, this work will be the foundation for a larger grant that will draw information related to function and pain from throughout the medical record for patients with joint replacement. With this additional information, we may be able to monitor implant performance with metrics that present well before prostheses are explanted. This will inform improved delivery of care to veterans with advanced hip or knee arthritis.
PROJECT_TITLE: Early Identification of Poorly Performing Joint Replacements

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lyme disease and other tickborne diseases pose a significant community public health threat, especially in northeastern, mid-Atlantic and mid-western portions of the United State where blacklegged ticks are abundant. While it has long been assumed that most human tick encounters are acquired locally in the vicinity of human habitations, the locations where tick encounters occur both on- and off-premises needs more study. This project will advance knowledge on the impact of environmentally-based tick and pathogen control when it is applied to single or multiple adjacent residential properties.

PHR: Project Narrative Sexual minority stress is an established contributor to poorer behavioral, mental, and physical health for gay and bisexual men, though the role of HIV-related stress within these models has gone largely unexplored. We will test a unified model of sexual minority and HIV-related stress on biomarkers of physiological stress (i.e., cortisol) and immune (i.e., viral load, CD4, cytokines) responses using twice-daily ecological momentary assessment (EMA) for 21 days and quarterly longitudinal follow-ups over 12 months to prospectively test the proposed model. We will use self-reported surveys and neurocognitive assessments to quantitatively examine the impact of these stressors on HIV-related health outcomes, and end by developing guidelines to inform the development of future interventions aimed at improving HIV treatment and prevent HIV transmission.
